meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay, well one thing that I'm very curious about is the membrane in terms of diffusion and movement of proteins and receptors. meeting_annotations.speaker: Alexis C. Komor
meeting_annotations.transcript: And so we work with immortalized cell lines and even with those when you dilute them too much, like they die. And so I imagine the same thing has to be true with tissues and there it's not even it's going to be so heterogeneous too. And I I like this word like holistic, like the holistic view of a cell and and I always think or like a tissue and when you're like again as a chemical biologist like we want to get molecular information about these systems and the more molecular information you get, the like less holistic information and like your holistic view starts to like break down. meeting_annotations.speaker: Michelle Farkas
meeting_annotations.transcript: So I can kind of add to what Alexis was talking about and you know following up. And one of the reasons why we use reporters is because we want to be able to incorporate and recapitulate or incorporate different and multiple cell types and recapitulate these you know three-dimensional and even two-dimensional but multicellular environments because you know all of this really does matter and it does make a difference what cells are nearby, you know what are what are the activity states of the cells that are nearby, you know even in terms of you know culturing so Alexis mentioned you know just the density of cells but also whether you culture the cells in two dimensions versus three dimensions right? You can have the same exact cell type but you have you know wildly different characteristics in terms of you know what's being expressed, what's being secreted, etc. Is is also just the the characteristics of the environment, things like stiffness, right? Because one of the things that that came up are you know how do we define these tissue units and cellular neighborhoods and are they different in different organs? They're absolutely different in different organs because you know some organs are more homogeneous, others are more heterogeneous and and the physical characteristics of different organs is also different. So you know being able to recapitulate all those things is extremely difficult and I and I'm interested to hear from you know the the physical tool people about how we can get more out of you know these systems because at this stage you know it's it's hard to do period.
